CLASS OFFICERS
ARE NOMINATED
Witchhawks Expected Before
Elections
VOTING NEXT WEEK
Nominations To Be Reopened
Previous To Elections
During the past week meetings
of the Sophomore, Junior and Senior Classes were held in order to
nominate men for class offices.
On Tuesday the 8th, the Junior
Class met. It was agreed that the
nominee for the presidency, who received the greatest amount of votes
should be duly elected, and the nominee with the next greatest number
should become vice-president. Lockard and Towbin were nominated for
president. For secretary, Cone,
Rutherford and Powell are the nominees; and for treasurer, Kyle,
Burk and MacDonald. Heinserling
was nominated for sergeant-atarms.
Two men represent the Junior
Class on the Student Council. For
these two positions eight men were
nominated: Yellot, Powell, Bloom,
Ruark, Schwartz, Lockha-rd, Meeks,
and Millard.
Another meeting of the class will
be held on Tuesday the 15th, at
which the nominations will be recpened and the elections held. The
time for voting will be from 12.20
to 1 o'clock.
The meeting of the Sophomore
Class was held on Monday the 7th.
As in the Junior elections, election
of the president and vice-president
will be fixed by the first and second
greatest number of votes.

CLASS ELECTIONS
TO BE HELD
The elections of class officers and Student Council
representatives of three upper
classes will take place this
week. The Junior election will
be held today, at 12.20, in the
C. E. Hall, while the Sophomores will cast their ballots
tomorrow, at the same hour.
The Senior election will take
place Thursday, after assembly. Nominations will be reopened before the ballot is
taken in all three meetings.

FRENCH PROF GIVES GEOGRAPHY
LESSON TO IGNORANT FRESHMAN
"In time, he became captain of
a pirate lugger of three cannon and
a crew of sixty men, and the coasters of Jersey still remember his exploits."
The foregoing English translation of a passage of Merimee's "Tamango" by a student in French One
was interrupted at about the conclusion of the sentences by the instructor's unexpected and devastating, "A propos, ou est Jersey ?"
After this had been repeated a
couple of times and finally translated into "By the way, where is
Jersey," the freshman, at last comprehended what was expected of
him, rattled his cranium (i.e., shook
his head) and slowly and sorrowfully replied that he did not know.
"A not unusual answer for a
freshman," caustically remarked the
instructor who then proceeded to
tell of the French first-year men
who thought that Texas was near
New York and that Brazil and
Argentine were included among the
Southern States, concluding with a
withering "Freshmen are like that."
Upon being interrogated as to
the leading product of the Isle of
Jersey, the potential future scholar
again pleaded ignorance. The in-

structor then proceeded to provide
enlightenment on both the situation
and product (cows) and was, moreover, so charitable and educational
as to explain the difference between
Jersey cows and those of the neighboring island of Guernsey. A last
chance was given the frosh to redeem himself in the eyes of his
classmates.

wondering if you happened to know
on what side of a cow to sit during the milking."
But the fates were unkind, for
Minerva, goddess of wisdom, had
never deigned to pour this highly
technical bit of knowledge into the
bewildered student's head. Another
member of the class, upon being
asked, guessed, "On the left side
I suppose."
The matter was then put to a
vote, most of the class voting for
the right side.
But democracy was doomed to
be discredited for the majority were
wrong. The left side is the one on
which to sit while milking a cow!
However little French the freshmen may have learned that period,
it is certain that they had acquired
a valuable bit of technical information which may, perhaps, be useful
on some future occasion. Quien
sabe?

held Monday, October 14th, at
12.30 in the Barn. An election
was necessitated by the fact
that Jack Deets, president of
the Barnstormers, did not return to Hopkins this fall.

Tomorrow, when the Hopkins
team trots out into the new stadium
of the University of Richmond, the
Southerners will see a badly crippled team.

head-up, and wary. This is the
hird game of their schedule, and the
team is anxious to chalk one up in
the win column. Thus far the
checks have been in the defeat
column, Lehigh winning to the tune
of 26 to 0, and Juniata, 7 to 0.
If the team can get a taste of
one victory they will be better set
for the remainder of the schedule.
When they first cross the goal line
of the Richmond field they will have
an incentive to keep them on the go
for the rest of the season.
